newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds end up, boosted by U.S., Moody's.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds end up, boosted by U.S., Moody's.

text.p: Argentine bonds finished higher Thursday after a sharp rally in U.S. Treasuries on soft retail sales figures and uplifting comments by Moody's Investors Service on Argentina's economy.
"The market rose on the retail sales. Many people are now ruling out a U.S. rate hike in July," said a trader at a local bank.
Argentina's FRB Brady bond due 2005 was up 3/8 at 94-1/4 while the dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 4 due 2002 was up $0.10 at 118.10.

A Moody's analyst said Thursday the rating agency may place Argentina's B1 sovereign rating on review for a possible upgrade some time in the next 12 to 18 months, but it is not currently considering a ratings change.
Despite the strong sentiment in the local market which led to busy activity this session, traders said performance in coming days will continue to depend on U.S. markets.
"The market will depend on how the U.S. (PPI) figures are tomorrow but I am optimistic we will get more gains," said another trader.
Call money rates fell to 5.5 percent from 5.58 percent.
